body: Dude, I don't have a crystal ball (which is obvious as I sold my AMC position when it hit 30) but selling apple just before a WDC is not exactly a sound financial decision. But, again, what the fuck would I know?

author: h2power237
body: There are larger potential announcements in the next couple of weeks.  More eco work in NYC area with getting buildings up to code and chargers at Mets field.  Company keeps adding to portfolio of annual renewal sales and has other arbitrage arrangements on the works with energy storage. There is some complicated engineering work here and behind the scenes connections in NY as well as WDC. Right place at right time.  Will do very well if they continue to execute.

author: skilliard7
body:
I've found I've had best luck with a balance of passive and active investing. I start with a portfolio of index funds based on factor investing(mostly chasing value premium),  and devote a small percentage of my portfolio to at most a few individual stocks where I'm confident they are undervalued.

I've had a lot of luck with this strategy so far. What I've learned from my early mistakes is:

1. Don't own anything unless you have a very good reason for owning it. If your reason is "their dividend is good", "their business is booming", or "they seem like a sustainable business", just stick with index funds. You need a compelling reason the market is not valuing them fairly, something that isn't priced in. When I bought SLV, it was because I knew it was a temporary liquidity crunch and that fed actions would drive inflation fears. When I bought LUMN, it was because I took a deep look into their financials and determined they were undervalued. When I bought Western Digital & Seagate, it was because I saw the potential for Chia to boost their earnings.

2. Buy as if you can't sell for 5 years. It's possible that after you buy, the price starts dropping and doesn't recover. If that happens, will you be comfortable holding it? If the answer is no, then either don't buy, or keep it to a very small position.

3. Don't buy a ton individual stocks to "diversify". 1 stock you are confident in accounting for 5% of your portfolio and a broad market index like VTI for the remaining 95% is safer than 40 manually picked stocks each representing 2.5%.

author: JourneymanInvestor
body: Funny I'm having the opposite experience this year. The naked calls have been reliably printing all year ($DIS, $WDC, $RBLX, etc)  whereas I'm constantly having to defend my short puts ($ARKK, $RKT, $RIOT, $GDRX).

author: spacegrab
body:
I'm about to buy a $900 headunit (digital media receiver) for my car. There's storage in there. 

WDC also owns Sandisk. 

> Flash drive pricing has increased by 30 percent, and buyers are seeing eight-week delays so far in 2021, due in part to worldwide pandemic shutdowns of manufacturing facilities.

author: rompish
body:
Robinhood does not let you sell Naked Options. You can only do that at a broker who allows margin accounts for options (Any big broker should do).

You can cover puts with either cash (for the full price of assignment) OR by buying a lower strike put which will limit your risk.

For calls you can cover with either owning 100 shares of WDC OR by buying a higher strike call .

So essentially in your case you would likely have to do an Iron condor, if you don't have enough cash/shares (or do not desire) to cover both put and call outright.

If I were you, and I really wanted a short strangle, I would do an Iron Condor with really wide wings, so it does not take much away from your total credit, but lets you place a defined risk trade with RH. The more capital you want to risk, the wider the wings you can make.

Using your strikes, we can do:

Buy 66 Put

Sell 69 Put

Sell $74 Call

Buy 77 Call
